choices.A: Single-tenancy is often more expensive and has less efficient resource utilization. Multitenancy may increase the risk of cross-customer exposure in the event of service vulnerabilities.
choices.D: The most secure design approach would be to give customers on-premises appliances, install agents on endpoints, and then remotely manage the service via a VPN.
choices.C: Due to the likelihood of large log volumes, the service provider should use a multitenancy model for the data storage tier, enable data deduplication for storage cost efficiencies, and encrypt data at rest.
choices.B: The managed service provider should outsource security of the platform to an existing cloud company. This will allow the new log service to be launched faster and with well-tested security controls.

questions.question_text:
A managed service provider is designing a log aggregation service for customers who no longer want to manage an internal SIEM infrastructure. The provider expects that customers will send all types of logs to them, and that log files could contain very sensitive entries. Customers have indicated they want on-premises and cloud-based infrastructure logs to be stored in this new service. An engineer, who is designing the new service, is deciding how to segment customers.
Which of the following is the BEST statement for the engineer to take into consideration?

discussion.content: Other practice tests online indicate A is the answer.
i honestly cannot pick between A and C. were looking for the best consideration, not a solution

comments.content: From the question: the engineer in only "deciding how to segment customers." Nothing else. Maybe options that make suggestions about anything other that segmenting customers should not be considered? For example, option B should not be considered.

discussion.content:
Maybe: A. Single-tenancy is often more expensive and has less efficient resource utilization. Multitenancy may increase the risk of cross-customer exposure in the event of service vulnerabilities.

The question does not ask for the best solution. It only asks for the: "BEST statement for the engineer to take into consideration"
Certainly, this is something the engineer needs to take into consideration.

Maybe: D. The most secure design approach would be to give customers on-premises appliances, install agents on endpoints, and then remotely manage the service via a VPN?
This makes a lot of sense. You can then zip and encrypt the aggreagated logs, and store them on the service. This way, there is far less uploading log files. This will make the process much more efficient, and secure.

comments.content: Likely not D due to this statement "for customers who no longer want to manage an internal SIEM infrastructure" - in other words, they don't want no stinkin' on-prem hardware.

"customers who no longer want to **manage** an internal SIEM infrastructure." 
Note: customers are not objecting to hosting the SIEM infrastructural, the customers just don't want to **manage** it.
Option D will "remotely **manage** the service via a VPN"
Then again: "Customers have indicated they want on-premises and **cloud-based** infrastructure logs."
Option D "would be to give customers **on-premises** appliances."
Maybe, through the VPN, the security engineer could download the cloud-based logs to the SIEM that is hosted by the customer.

questions.question_text:
At a meeting, the systems administrator states the security controls a company wishes to implement seem excessive, since all of the information on the company's web servers can be obtained publicly and is not proprietary in any way. The next day the company's website is defaced as part of an SQL injection attack, and the company receives press inquiries about the message the attackers displayed on the website.
Which of the following is the FIRST action the company should take?

choices.C: Establish chain of custody for all systems to which the systems administrator has access.
choices.D: Conduct a detailed forensic analysis of the compromised system.
choices.E: Inform the communications and marketing department of the attack details.
choices.A: Refer to and follow procedures from the company's incident response plan.
choices.B: Call a press conference to explain that the company has been hacked.

discussion.content: A. Refer to and follow procedures from the company's incident response plan.

Selected Answer: B
It's between A and B and I'm leaning towards B as the answer.

A wants to "escalate the security issue" I don't think we escalate security issues to leadership. Seems like we expect them to fix the issue if it's escalated to them.

B seems more appropriate because it tells leadership we have a vulnerability that can lead to a data breach ($$) which can result in negative media attention ($$$). Then, a recommendation is made.

Selected Answer: B
Because this is a banking app, it's better to go with more caution. Options B and C are the most cautious options, but C is too informal. B's wording sounds professional, and has the caution I'd expect for banking.

This is A. 

B and C is not how you would email leadership team.
D is too technical.... might want to lower down the technicality when addressing issue to leadership.

Thus A would be the best in this case.
" BEST conveys the business impact " Only B conveys any real business impact, going with B on this one - which might sound crazy because everywhere else online lists A/D

Maybe: H. Load balancer ?
Because: 1. Reuse of the existing network infrastructure
Since there are now two internet connections, a load balancer would help optimize those internet connections.
Pretty annoying that they called DRM just rights management in this question, messed with my brain.

comments.content: Get used to it. They do that a lot. In another question they call a WAF an "application firewall."

But SSL VPN is used with a web browser. 
From the question there is a requirement for "Access to the corporate applications."
Unless those applications are web-based, I am not sure you would be able to run them through a web browser.

discussion.content: SSL VPN is likely the "better" answer because it is slightly less cumbersome in that is doesn't require the introduction of a new VPN client and potential changes to the existing clients/network. In this way, SSL VPN would be more in line with the standup requirement: 1. Reuse of the existing network infrastructure.

Why not "A. IPSec VPN" instead of "E. SSL VPN" ?
None of the answers seem wrong, it just seems like IPSec VPN might also be right.

questions.question_text:
As a result of an acquisition, a new development team is being integrated into the company. The development team has BYOD laptops with IDEs installed, build servers, and code repositories that utilize SaaS. To have the team up and running effectively, a separate Internet connection has been procured.
A stand up has identified the following additional requirements:
1. Reuse of the existing network infrastructure
2. Acceptable use policies to be enforced
3. Protection of sensitive files
4. Access to the corporate applications
Which of the following solution components should be deployed to BEST meet the requirements? (Choose three.)

choices.D: An open distributed transaction ledger that requires proof of work to append entries.
choices.A: An internal key infrastructure that allows users to digitally sign transaction logs
choices.B: An agreement with an entropy-as-a-service provider to increase the amount of randomness in generated keys.
choices.C: A publicly verified hashing algorithm that allows revalidation of message integrity at a future date.

discussion.content: feels like it's talking about block chain?

The answer could be A or D.
Lets see:
D. Based on https://resources.infosecinstitute.com/topic/alternative-distributed-ledger-architectures/
Meet the following requeriments reduced transaction time, security, message integrity, cryptographic security but
asynchronous.

A. Based on moz-extension://382a19ac-8980-4165-98a9-b34625cd4d3d/https://www.jite.org/documents/Vol9/JITEv9IIPp061-077Murray804.pdf
and this https://www.ibm.com/cloud/learn/database-security
You can meet the following requeriments reduced transaction time, security, message integrity, cryptographic security and
asynchronous.
So, i vote A.

Why not: C. A publicly verified hashing algorithm that allows revalidation of message integrity at a future date ? 
Option A seems to only apply to transaction logs. The question is more concerned with message integrity than transaction logs. 
Increasing messages integrity is specifically mentioned in the question. Option C is the only option that addresses that.
I'm going with A here as well. an internal key infrastructure is a short and pretty complete solution to the problem the question asks.

comments.content: Option A seems to state that the internal key infrastructure will only be used for signing transaction logs. Certainly they will need a system to do more than that.

discussion.content:
An agreement with an entropy-as-a-service provider to increase the amount of randomness in generated keys.
- EaaS is typically used with IoT

A publicly verified hashing algorithm that allows revalidation of message integrity at a future date.
- does not address traffic time

An open distributed transaction ledger that requires proof of work to append entries
- does not address traffic time or cryptography

An internal key infrastructure that allows users to digitally sign transaction logs
- meets all the stated objectives

comments.content:
Is this even a fair question? For example: "reduced transaction time." Reduce transaction time from what? What are they using now? Then it goes on: "increased security and message integrity, and improved cryptographic security." Again, from what? 
Nothing you do to increase security is going to reduced transaction time. Unless, maybe, you are using some really awful security system now, and replace it with something better. But with no mention of what is being used now, what are we to compare this to? Also, are just adding something new, or replacing something that is already existing?

discussion.content: I think is A. Many other dumps have A as the answer, it does not mean that A is the answer and another dump has entropy as the answer. I did some research and I could not find the right answer.
